Graphical abstract This review summarizes the current advances of MXenes for perovskite solar cells, along with the analysis of existing issues and the perspective to outlook in-depth developments of MXenes for photovoltaics. Perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have been developed over the past decade as the forefront of the state-of-the-art photovoltaic technologies owing to their high efficiency and low cost, where nanostructured functional materials play key roles in performance optimization. As a versatile class of two-dimensional (2D) materials, transition metal carbides/nitrides MXenes have gained enormous attentions in PSCs since 2018 due to their superior properties such as excellent metallic conductivity, abundant surface functional groups, tunable work functions, high optical transparency, and mechanical robustness. The explorations of MXenes are of significance in performance promotion and commercialization expansion of devices. As such, this review focuses on the diversified advantages of MXenes, comprehensively summarizing their applications and developments in PSCs as additives, electron/hole transporting layers, interfacial engineering layers, and electrodes in sequence and explaining the relevant mechanisms behind. Simultaneously, the problems emerged from the related studies are considered and the corresponding suggestions like opening up the type of MXenes usage, taking further insight of the modulation of surface termination groups on Fermi levels, understanding the effect on energy level structures of perovskite or other functional layers, and realizing commercialization, etc. are provided for the future in-depth explorations. This review is intended to provide overall perspective of the current status of MXenes and highlight the direction for the future advancements in MXenes design and processes towards efficient, stable, large-area, and low-cost PSCs. Keywords MXenes Two-dimensional materials Perovskite solar cells Photovoltaic technologies Environment 1 Introduction Towards the ever-increasing global energy crisis and environmental issues, developing alternative, renewable, sustainable, and low-cost energy resources is in great urgency [1–4]. As the abundance and environmental friendliness of sunlight, solar energy has been considered as a promising technology, while the solar cells have been widely developed and explored [5–8]. Among the emerging photovoltaic (PV) technologies, perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have gained tremendous attention due to their high absorption coefficients, appropriate bandgap, high carrier mobility, long carrier lifetime, and charge diffusion lengths [9–13]. These attractive characteristics of PSCs enabled an incredibly rapid development of power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) from 3.8% to 25.7% within more than a decade of research investigation, which was comparable to silicon-based solar cells [14–17]. However, there still remain some key challenges that hinder the commercialization process, including long-term instability, toxic components of lead (Pb), large-area fabrication, hysteresis etc. [18–23]. Perovskite films exhibit intrinsic instability that leads to the rapid degradation upon exposure in air. Thus, protecting methods like passivating on perovskite films from degradants is in great importance for extending their lifetime and making them feasible for large-scale device fabrication [24]. Besides, the presence of lead in mostly-applied perovskites raises serious concerns of health and environment due to the toxic element Pb2+, indicating further explorations and designs for lead-free perovskite devices. The efficiency of PSCs with small active area has been comparable to that of Si solar cells, but the large-area fabrication of PSCs will result in obvious decrease of performance. So continuous explorations on high-quality large-area perovskite films with excellent carrier mobility by controlling their crystallization and uniformity are crucial. In this case, two-dimensional (2D) nano-structured materials with unique properties such as high charge carrier mobility, high optical transparency, and especially tunable electronic structure have gained immense applications to overcome the challenges above and promote the device performance. Their bandgap and work function can be extensively tuned by doping and passivation methods, making it possible to tune the selective carrier extraction with low energy losses and limited surface recombination, thus rendering PSCs performance enhancement [25]. Besides, owing to their size control of atomic-scale thickness and ideal contact layer materials in thin films, 2D materials can be applied as additives, electron/hole transport layers, interlayers, and electrodes in PSCs, providing diverse possibilities for materials adaptation options [26]. Moreover, the use of 2D materials can limit the decomposition of perovskite induced by moisture, which effectively maintains the long-term stability of PSCs. Multifunctional applications of 2D materials indicate their significant potential and pave the way for high performance, large-area, low-cost, and stable PSCs towards industrial exploitation [27,28]. As a family of 2D materials, layered transition metal carbides and nitrides MXenes were first reported by Gogotsi et al. in 2011, which were synthesized by a selective etching process from MAX phases [29]. The formula of MXenes is determined to be M n +1X n T x (n = 1, 2, 3, 4), where M represents the early transition metals (Ti, V, Mo, etc.), X represents carbon and/or nitrogen, and T x represents the surface terminations (usually –O, –OH, and/or –F) [30–32]. The surface functional groups directly affect the properties of MXenes, coupled with their unique 2D structure, making them exhibit excellent electrical conductivity, tunable work function (WF), hydrophilicity, and flexibility [33–36]. Thus, MXenes have been widely investigated in supercapacitors [37–39], lithium-ion batteries [40–42], biomedical fields [43–45], sensors [46–48], electromagnetic interference shielding [49–51], catalysis [52–55], and light-emitting diodes [56]. In this context, MXenes also exhibited promising potential and were explored as effective alternative materials for various components of PSCs owing to their unique properties [57–59]. In 2018, Ti3C2T x MXene was first reported as an additive in active layer of PSCs [60]. Since then, its applications have been widely extended to additives in transporting layers, electron/hole transporting layers (ETL/HTL), electrodes, and interface engineering [61,62]. Specifically, by means of composites doping [63,64], surface functional groups regulating [65], exploration of oxidation process [66], heterojunctions constructing [67], and the essential physical processes investigating [68], some interesting results of MXenes like the carrier mobility enhancement, transition from metallic material to semiconductor after heavy oxidation, work functions alignments, defects passivation, and stability optimizations are obtained with promoted performances of PSCs. All the results aroused our interest and confident for further applications of MXenes in PSCs and other photovoltaics. To get an overall perspective of the present achievements and to give in-depth advice for next stage of development, a systematic and timely summary of the essential physical processes related to the optimization of MXene-based PSCs is highly necessary. On account of this perspective, this review summarizes the current advances of MXenes for PSCs. Different roles of currently applied MXenes were categorized and presented with a comprehensive discussion. The corresponding advantages and the problems limiting the devices performance were particularly summarized. An analysis of the existing issues is eventually provided, along with a perspective to prospect the in-depth development of MXenes for photovoltaics. 2 Fabrication and characteristics of MXenes MXenes are a large and rapidly developing family of 2D materials derived from their precursors MAX phases with the formula of M n +1X n T x , while the layered ternary transition metal carbides and/or nitrides separated by A-atom layers of MAX phases are generally indicated as M n +1AX n [69,70]. Fig. 1 (a) exhibits the periodic table with colored elements that are possible for the combination of MAX phases and MXenes, where M represents early transition metal, A indicates group IIIA or IVA elements, X indicates carbon and/or nitrogen, and T x are surface terminations [71,72]. In MAX phases, different octahedral edge-sharing blocks are formed by M and X with A-elements interlayered, leading to various stacking arrangements of M2AX, M3AX2, M4AX3, and M5AX4 [73]. Thus, MXenes with different stoichiometric combinations can be generated by removing the A atom layer from the corresponding MAX phases and typically classified as M2X, M3X2, M4X3, and M5X4 (Fig. 1b) [74]. To date, more than 100 species of MAX and MXenes have been theoretically predicted, Ti3C2T x has become the most expanding and widely studied MXene among them, while Fig. 1(c) indicates the relative process by eliminating the A atom from Ti3AlC2 [29,75]. Due to the strong bonding interactions between M and A atoms, conventional mechanical exfoliation methods to obtain MXenes seem impossible. Thus, chemical methods are employed to selectively etch MAX phases for the metallic M−A bonds that are more active than that for ionic and/or covalent M−X bonds [76]. In terms of this aspect, wet chemical etching methods using HF or HCl+LiF to exfoliate MAX phases are the most efficient and widely applied procedures [14,71]. As scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images are shown in Fig. 1(d and e), the blocked Ti3AlC2 MAX phase became accordion-shaped multilayered Ti3C2T x nanosheets after the successful etching of Al layers, where Al atoms were dissolved in HF and formed AlF3, leading to the expansion of layer space [77]. And then, monolayered Ti3C2T x nanosheets can be obtained by further exfoliation (Fig. 1f) [75]. Besides of this, many other procedures like molten salt etching [78,79], alkaline hydrothermal treatment [80], and electrochemical etching [81,82] were employed and high-quality monolayered MXene nanosheets were obtained as well, making it more diversified for development [83]. In detail, molten salt etching method is in contract to the wet chemical etching, in which selective etching of A layer from MAX phase occurred in a molten fluoride salt under inert gas atmosphere at a high temperature like 550 °C. Delamination of multilayered MXene particles into monolayers is achieved by organic solvent intercalation and sonication. As for alkaline hydrothermal treatment, the method avoids the corrosive and harmful effects of HF, using a NaOH-assisted hydrothermal process to etch MAX phase to obtain MXene nanosheets without F terminations. This fluorine-free approach also provides a strategy for exploring new MXenes when amphoteric or acidic elements must be removed. Moreover, electrochemical etching is also proven as a less hazardous way to fabricate and handle MXenes. In contrast to wet chemical etching methods using HF or LiF/HCl, the electrochemical etching does not concern fluoride ions during etching and demonstrates a potential way for selectively etching A layer from MAX phase without fluoride ions and –F terminations. Therefore, there has been diverse approaches for MXenes obtaining according to the varying experimental requirements, indicating their multiplicity and wide range of applications. MXenes demonstrate appealing structural, chemical, and optoelectronic properties with high conductivity, high carrier mobility, abundance of surface functional groups, hydrophilicity that allows for handling from aqueous solution, tunable work function, and chemistry, indicating a significant potential in photovoltaic applications [84–87]. In MXenes, the species and the constituent compositions play the decisive roles in their configurations and regulating their properties, while the surface functional groups also have important impact owing to the large surface area inherited from distinctive 2D structure [88,89]. Typically, most MXenes exhibit excellent conductivities and carrier mobilities like ∼104 S cm−1 and 1 cm2 V−1 s−1 for the most studied Ti3C2T x [90], while numerous studies have demonstrated their metallic behavior by theories and experiments [91,92]. Moreover, some MXenes, such as Nb2CT x and Mo2CT x , can even accomplish superconductivity after tuning the surface terminations and regulating M atoms in their structures, whose results were made a comparison of different functional groups like –OH, –F, –O, –Se, and –NH, demonstrating the correlation of conductivity and resistivity with the composition and structure of MXenes [93,94]. The surface terminations of MXenes affect their electronic properties including band structure and work function [95–97]. As a large number of theoretical studies are conducted, the majority of MXenes are determined to have metallic/semi-metallic energy band structures, while Sc2CT2, Ti2CO2, Zr2CO2, Hf2CO2, etc. are reported to exhibit semiconductor properties and have band gaps that range from 0.24 to 1.8 eV [92,98,99]. Subsequent research also reported the semiconductive behavior of Mo2CT x and Mo2TiC2T x MXenes [100,101]. Chemically, MXene nanosheets are easily oxidized when exposed to oxygenated environment or light, leading to the creation of metal oxide nanocrystals [91]. For instance, the anatase or rutile TiO2 might present when Ti3C2T x MXene got oxidized, while a transformation of metallic property to semiconductor property occurred after heavy oxidation [102,103]. On basis of these, researchers are exploring solutions to inhibit oxidation process to achieve long-term applications of MXene [104]. Meanwhile, utilizing appropriate control of the oxidation to generate distinctive hybrid structure is also attractive. Besides, the work functions of MXenes are directly related to their surface functional groups [105]. A wide range from 1.6 to 8.0 eV is demonstrated for Sc2C(OH)2 and Cr2CO2, which is wider than that of the typical metals [106]. The surface terminations can draw electrons and change the surface dipole moment and thus regulate the work function of MXenes, suggesting large modulation of work function utilized and great potential in electronic devices [107-109]. 3 Applications of MXenes in PSCs 3.1 Engineering of MXene as additives The additive engineering for functional layers has been demonstrated to be an efficient method to enhance the performance of PSCs [59,110]. Typically, additives served in active layer or transporting layers can exhibit multiple functions, such as tuning the WFs by facilitating the electronic structures, optimizing the crystallization of perovskite layer, passivating the defects, and enhancing the charge transfer [111–113]. On basis of this, the first exploration of MXene in PSCs was initiated by Guo et al. in 2018, where Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets were employed as an additive to optimize the crystallization of perovskite layer and boost the charge transfer [60]. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), Ti3C2T x MXene can effectively tune the crystallization process and improve the grain size of perovskite film. Owing to the interaction between the functional Ti3C2T x and MAI, the nucleus of perovskite generated around the Ti3C2T x nanosheets and the number of the nucleus are suppressed, indicating the retarded nucleation and growth process. Better crystallization of perovskite with less defect states can be obtained. Besides, benefiting from high conductivity and unique structure, MXene nanosheets can serve as a “carrier bridge” through the grain boundary and accelerate the charge transfer, giving rise to an improvement of PCE from 15.5% to 17.4% at an optimal ratio of 0.03 wt% (Fig. 2b). The enhanced transfer mobility is further confirmed by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis and shown in Fig. 2(c). This work paves the way for further explorations of MXenes in PSCs. Similarly, Cl-terminated Ti3C2T x quantum dots (QDs) were introduced into perovskite layer as additives to optimize the performance of PSCs by Liu et al. [114]. Due to the modification of –Cl surface termination, a strong interaction between MXene and Pb2+ are formed, leading to regular-grew and better crystallized perovskite films with less trap states (Fig. 2d). In addition, Fig. 2(e) exhibits the elemental distribution of each element for Ti3C2Cl x and perovskite. Ti3C2Cl x QDs formed a top-down increasing gradient distribution, which is favorable for the oriented growth of high-quality perovskite. Besides, The Cl terminated Ti3C2Cl x QDs can coordinate with Sn4+ and Pb2+ as a “carrier bridge”, which are beneficial for the charge extraction between the ETL and perovskite layer as illustrated in Fig. 2(f). The terminations of MXenes can induce the formation of electrostatic dipoles that affect WFs of perovskite layers [33,115]. Thus, the energy level of perovskite layer can also be adjusted by Ti3C2Cl x QDs as shown in Fig. 2(g), where an obtained better energy-level alignment between ETL and perovskite layer demonstrates a promoted charge transfer and an enhanced PCE of 21.31% with a long-term stability. Furthermore, Agresti et al. reported the effect of Ti3C2T x MXene with various surface terminations on WFs tuning and interface engineering between perovskite and ETL [115]. The WF of perovskite layer could be shifted in a range of 4.72–4.37 eV without affecting other electronic properties, thus leading to an improved charge transfer between perovskite film and TiO2 ETL. The inimitable WF adjustment of MXenes reported in this work demonstrates novel designs of MXenes for photovoltaic devices in the future [116]. Recently, Zhang et al. deposited MAPbBr3 nanocrystals on few-layered Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets to form heterojunction by means of an in-situ solution growth method [117], as Fig. 2(h) exhibits the corresponding preparation schematic of MAPbBr3/Ti3C2T x heterostructure. Fig. 2(i) depicts the band alignment and charge transfer between MAPbBr3 and Ti3C2T x . A facilitated carrier transfer from perovskite to Ti3C2T x MXene is accomplished due to the better-matched energy levels, which is also favorable to the performance enhancement for the relative PSCs. Moreover, the charge extraction and transfer are greatly associated with the crystal distortions like lattice strain and defects induced, which determines the performance of PSCs. In 2021, Zhou et al. proposed a defect passivation method that incorporated Ti3C2T x into the bulk and surface of perovskite film to reduce the lattice tensile strain [118]. Owing to the stronger binding energy of Pb–Cl (301 kJ mol−1) compared with 248 kJ mol−1 for Pb–Br, the interaction between Pb2+ and Cl atoms of Ti3C2Cl x is favorable for dragging the adjacent perovskite grains closer while anchoring the Pb atoms, thus rendering perovskite the reduced lattice tensile strain as illustrated in Fig. 2(j). Fig. 2(k) shows the carrier loss caused by the strains and defects of perovskite film under light irradiation, while there will be more holes accumulated after Ti3C2T x incorporation that contributes to higher voltage for the devices. Finally, an ultrahigh voltage up to 1.702 V with nearly unchanged stability over 100 days of PSCs is achieved. Additionally, by coupling the benefits of Ti3C2T x and cesium (Cs), Bati et al. prepared functionalized Ti3C2T x nanosheets doped with Cs ions and injected them into PbI2 precursor solution via two-step fabrication method for fabrication of PSCs, as Fig. 3 (a) shows the schematic illustration of these two additives introduced to the device [119]. The corresponding computational studies on the interaction between Ti3C2T x and perovskite indicate highly crystallized perovskite film, which can effectively reduce the defect density, benefit the charge transfer, and enhance device performance (Fig. 3b). Zhao et al. reported the incorporation of Ti3C2T x nanosheets and PbI2, rendering better crystallization of perovskite film that left no residue PbI2 with enlarged grain size (Fig. 3c) [120]. Such introduction of Ti3C2T x in perovskite film shifts the WF of MAPbI3 from 3.82 to 4.12 eV, generating better match of perovskite layer much closer to that of ETL as shown in Fig. 3(d). Thus, efficient electron extraction and transfer are achieved, leading to an ∼18% promotion compared to the control devices with a champion PCE of 19.27%. Besides the additive of Ti3C2T x , V2CT x nanosheets were also employed into PbI2 precursor solution for fabrication of perovskite film by Li et al. [121]. The appropriate mass content of V2CT x can optimize the morphology of perovskite film with better crystallization and enhance the hydrophobicity of the perovskite layer, rendering an enhanced PCE of 17.61% (increased by 17% compared to the control) and more outstanding stability than the devices without additives. This study presents an effective approach for performance improvement for PSCs by V2CT x and broadens the applicability of MXenes in photovoltaics. More recently, Jin et al. reported employing Ti3C2T x nanosheets as nano-dopants in the 2D (BA)2(MA)4Pb5I16 Ruddlesden-Popper (RP) perovskite absorber [64]. High conductivity and unique structure of Ti3C2T x nanosheets raise the promoted crystallinity and orientation with passivated trap states in the three-dimensional (3D) phase of the perovskite film, leading to accelerated carrier transfer process in vertical direction. Thus, the PCE of the devices is increased from 13.69% to 15.71%, while exhibiting excellent stability. Furthermore, to address the instability and toxicity of lead, all-inorganic lead-free double perovskite Cs2AgBiBr6 with high stability and environmental friendliness is widely explored. Considering the poor absorbance and low carrier transfer mobility [122], Ti3C2T x was introduced into Cs2AgBiBr6 to optimize its grain size and electrical properties [68]. As exhibited in Fig. 3(e), the weak van der Waals (vdW) interaction at the interface of Cs2AgBiBr6 and Ti3C2T x is demonstrated, while effectively weakening the Fermi level pinning (FLP). The band structure calculation shown in Fig. 3(f) indicates the adjusted valence band of Cs2AgBiBr6 through its Fermi level via high work function of Ti3C2T x , which gives rise to the carrier mobility and the performance of devices. These studies demonstrate effective approaches for enhancing performance of PSCs by MXenes, and exhibit the great potential for further applications in photovoltaic devices. The key parameters for MXenes as additives in perovskite layer of PSCs are summarized in Table S1. Apart from the modification in active layer in PSCs, the exploration and regulation of ETLs are also crucial for selective charge extraction, blocking carriers recombination, and rectifying photocurrent to enhance the devices’ performance [123]. In 2019, SnO2-Ti3C2T x nanocomposites with different concentrations of Ti3C2T x as ETLs were constructed in low-temperature processed PSCs [63]. The device architecture of typical SnO2-Ti3C2T x as ETL is shown in Fig. 4 (a), and the matching cross-sectional SEM image of the device is presented in Fig. 4(b). Owing to the high conductivity, energy-level alignment, and the unique nanostructure of Ti3C2T x , superior electron extraction and mobility with low charge transfer resistance at the perovskite/ETL interface are obtained, rendering an enhanced PCE from 17.23% to 18.34% as shown in Fig. 4(c). In the meantime, a PCE of 5.28% based on Ti3C2T x -only as ETL is achieved, demonstrating the possibility and potential of pristine MXenes working as ETLs in PSCs. Moreover, to explore the fundamental understanding of the crystallization processes for highly crystalline and stable perovskite films, Yang et al. reported an in-situ synchrotron-based 2D grazing-incidence X-ray diffraction (2D-GIXRD) technique to investigate the modulation of perovskite crystallization based on the Ti3C2T x QDs-modified SnO2 ETL [124]. As Fig. 4(d) shows, the perovskite film fabricated on Ti3C2T x QDs-modified SnO2 ETL differs from that based on the pristine SnO2. Bright diffraction rings and spots starting can be observed from 12 s, suggesting a rapid nucleation process during the spin-coating period and a formation of intermediate perovskite phase upon anti-solvent treatment. Benefiting from the improved crystallization and the excellent charge extraction of Ti3C2T x QDs-modified SnO2 ETL, an outstanding PCE up to 23.3% with long-term stability was accomplished. More recently, Wu et al. reported the use of SnO2-MXene composite ETL for enhancing interfacial contact and passivating defects at the ETL/perovskite interface [125]. Commonly, the lattice distortion of perovskite film induced by interface lattice mismatching will result in a slow carrier extraction and transfer [126]. In this work, the grazing-incidence wide-angle X-ray scattering (GIWAXS) patterns of perovskite/SnO2-MXene have a brighter scattering ring at ∼10.0 nm−1 of q (Fig. 4e). The sharper (110) diffraction peak indicates a better crystallinity and out-of-plane orientation of perovskite film fabricated upon SnO2-MXene ETL [127,128]. The lattice matching of perovskite and MXene suppresses the stress concentration caused by interfacial mismatch, thus leading to high-quality oriented perovskite films. Besides, Fig. 4(f) shows the energy levels of each layer of the device after introducing MXene, where the maximum value of the valence band of ETL has a shift from −7.72 to −7.93 eV. The downshift is beneficial for blocking the holes migration and rendering enhanced photoelectric properties of PSCs. Finally, the J sc was up to 25.07 mA cm−2, and the PCE of device got an improvement by 15%. In 2021, Zheng et al. processed the defect density controlling of perovskite films by SnO2/Ti3C2T x ETL with different ratios [129]. In this work, the addition of Ti3C2T x is not primarily enhancing the electrical conductivity of ETL. Instead, the qualities of perovskite film including the defect density, compactness, crystal size, surface roughness etc. become controllable by changing doping ratios of Ti3C2T x , where the defect density is greatly reduced from 5.65 × 1015 to 2.25 × 1015 cm−3 as shown in Fig. 4(g). A significantly enhancement of PCE from 16.28% to 20.35% is obtained along with the improved environmental stability. Furthermore, to achieve better energy alignment and charge transfer of SnO2-MXene ETLs, Yin et al. reported a functionalized Ti3C2T x modified with fluoroalkylsilane and dodecyltrimethoxysilane molecules [130]. As shown in Fig. 4(h), the energy levels of SnO2 ETLs with differently functionalized Ti3C2T x got adjustable that can better match the band alignment for the device. In the meantime, the functionalized Ti3C2T x with high conductivity and carrier mobility can form zero Schottky barrier heterojunction with SnO2, significantly improving the charge transfer and optimizing the crystallization of perovskite film. Finally, a substantial increase of PCE from 20.98% to 24.12% with outstanding stability is obtained, demonstrating the prospective applications of MXenes for photovoltaic devices. In 2020, Chen et al. utilized Ti3C2T x QDs (TQDs) with the average size of ∼5.1 nm and the thickness of ∼1.0 nm to incorporate into ETL and perovskite layer to obtain a device architecture of FTO/c-TiO2/m-TiO2-TQD/perovskite-TQD/Spiro-OMeTAD-Cu1.8S/Au as shown in Fig. 5 (a), where c-TiO2 represents compact TiO2 and /m-TiO2 represents mesoporous TiO2 [131]. The introduction of TQDs not only reduces the interfacial defects and enhances the charge injection from perovskite layer to ETL, but also improves the crystallization and carrier mobility of perovskite film. The reduced grain boundaries and defect density of perovskite layer are achieved by passivating the charge recombination centers, thus leading to better carrier separation and transfer. As a result, a significant enhancement of hysteresis-free PCE from 18.31% to 21.64% with long-term ambient stability and light stability was accomplished. Similarly, Ge et al. introduced TQDs into perovskite layer and inserted Ti3C2T x nanosheets into TiO2 ETL to optimize the performance of PSCs [132]. Fig. 5(b) exhibits the schematic diagram of the device based on Ti3C2T x modified perovskite layer and TiO2 ETL with the approach of charge transfer. The TQDs process a passivation on the perovskite film to reduce the defect density and to enhance the crystallization, while accelerating the electron extraction and mobility of ETL. The co-optimization renders a boosted PCE of PSCs from 12.0% further to 17.1% with reduced hysteresis, demonstrating the crucial action of Ti3C2T x MXene in PSCs. Recently, a multi-dimensional heterojunction composed of SnO2, TiO2, and Ti3C2T x was conducted and applied as ETL in PSCs by Huang et al. [133]. The nanoscale heterojunction was fabricated by in-situ rooted of zero-dimensional anatase TiO2 QDs with Ti3C2T x nanosheets surrounded on the 3D SnO2 nanoparticles. The device structure and energy level diagram of the PSC using multi-dimensional conductive network is shown in Fig. 5(c). The heterojunction offers the enhanced transmittance so that the active layer is capable of receiving more photons, while the crystallization of upper perovskite film is enhanced, achieving more amount carrier and superior charge transfer. The suitable band alignment of heterojunction with the perovskite layer can suppress the holes transport and decrease the interface impedance, giving rise to an optimized PCE of 19.14% with long-term maintained stability. Moreover, Ti3C2T x was incorporated with TiO2 as a multifunctional ETL in inorganic lead-free Cs2AgBiBr6 double PSCs to solve the issues of the instability and the toxicity of lead by Li et al., as shown in Fig. 5(d) [134]. The doping of Ti3C2T x not only promotes the electron extraction and charge mobility of ETL, but also changes the ETL’s wettability and optimizes the crystallization of the Cs2AgBiBr6 film. Thus, an enhancement of PCE by more than 40% to 2.81% with significantly suppressed hysteresis (Fig. 5e) and a retention rate of 93% for PCE stored under ambient air for 15 days are obtained. Besides the applications of Ti3C2T x , other MXene like Nb2CT x was also explored as an external additive into SnO2 ETL by Niu et al. in 2021 [135]. The detailed synthesis process of SnO2-Nb2CT x mixed solution is shown in Fig. 5(f). The incorporation of Nb2CT x can promote the lattice spacing facets, rendering a better surface energy and less defects of the ETL. Moreover, the perovskite films processed on the SnO2-Nb2CT x indicate superior qualities with enhanced crystallization and effective carrier mobility as well. Therefore, a champion PCE of 22.86% for PSCs based on Nb2CT x dopant from 18.96% of the pristine device was achieved along with 98% retention of the origin efficiencies over one month, demonstrating an insight into the preparation of regulated ETL for boosting the PCE and stability of PSCs as well as extending the applications of MXenes in photovoltaic devices. Additionally, Ti3C2T x MXene was introduced into both perovskite film and ETL in NiOx-based inverted PSCs by Saranin et al. in 2021 [136]. Fig. 5(g and h) exhibits the schematic diagram of the MXene-based p-i-n devices and the related energy levels of each layer. In particular, the doping of MXene results in the suitable adjustments of WFs and proper energy level alignment of perovskite/ETL interfaces. A reduction of defect density of perovskite film and the enhanced charge transfer in Phenyle c-61 butyric acid methyle acid (PCBM) are achieved as well, leading to the superior performance of PCE exceeding 19% with stabilized power output. The conducted approach provides an effective method for engineering inverted PSCs and promises the future scalability on large area devices. Furthermore, Hussain et al. proposed Mo2CT x and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) to modify the HTLs in PSCs owing to their high conductivity, tunable WF, and excellent carrier mobility for the first time in 2021 [137]. Fig. 6 (a) shows the schematic diagram of device architecture based on Mo2CT x -CNTs@PEDOT:PSS as HTL and the related cross-sectional SEM image, while the energy level of each functional layer is obtained in Fig. 6(b). It can be seen that the modified HTL serves as easy charge transfer channels between perovskite layer and ITO. The introduction of Mo2CT x -CNTs enhances the internal electric field and interrelates with the band position, thus promoting the rapid charge separation and transfer. Higher performances of PSCs are finally obtained based on Mo2CT x -CNTs@PEDOT:PSS as shown in Fig. 6(c). Besides, Hussain et al. conducted a simple solution process that construct Ti3C2T x /WO3 heterojunction to optimize the PEDOT:PSS HTL of PSCs [138]. Fig. 6(d) illustrates the device architecture based on MXene/WO3@PEDOT:PSS and its cross-sectional SEM image. The different layers with good interfacial contact are favorable for the separation and transfer of carriers. The corresponding energy level diagram of the device is obtained in Fig. 6(e), indicating that altered energy band alignment of HTL and perovskite layer renders imminent interaction through their interface region. Finally, the enhanced performances of the devices are demonstrated by J-V curves shown in Fig. 6(f). These proposed modifications exhibit great potential of MXenes for engineering efficient HTLs in PSCs. The key parameters for MXenes as additives in ETLs/HTLs of PSCs are summarized in Table S2. In summary, the engineering of MXenes as additives can effectively optimize the crystallinity of perovskites, tuning the WFs of the active layers and transport layers through the electronic structure modification. Promoted charge transfer characteristics with less defects and non-radiative recombination are accomplished by the excellent passivation of MXenes, thus giving rise to the incredible performance for PSCs. However, the use of MXenes as additives are still limited in counting over kinds, such as the most studied Ti3C2T x and preliminarily explored V2CT x , Nb2CT x , and Mo2CT x . Thus, more diverse MXenes are necessary to be explored to open up the opportunities to further enhance the performance of each functional layer. Meanwhile, the future studies should pay more attention to the surface terminations modulation of MXenes, which is directly associated with their WFs and optoelectronic properties. Besides, deep theory calculations and mechanism understanding for regulation of MXenes along with their coordination with perovskite layer and other functional layers are crucial for future design of high-performance devices. 3.2 MXenes as ETLs Apart from being additives, MXenes are promised for acting as ETLs due to their abundant surface terminations and tunable WFs as well. In 2019, the potential of Ti3C2T x -only serving as ETL in low-temperature processed planar PSCs was found, but the performance of the devices was not satisfactory [63]. Therefore, the modification of Ti3C2T x was conducted by ultraviolet (UV)-ozone treatment to promote its adaptability as ETL [65]. Fig. 7 (a) shows the structure of the device based on Ti3C2T x with or without UV-ozone treatment. The corresponding results reveal that the UV-ozone treatment on Ti3C2T x nanosheets with optimum time can render it more suitable as ETL by generating more oxide-like TiO bonds with the adjustments of WFs. Moreover, the properties of the perovskite/Ti3C2T x interface are enhanced, which facilitate the charge transfer and block the recombination (Fig. 7b). Thus, comprehensive enhancements of J sc, V oc, and FF are obtained that result in a much higher PCE of 17.17% with long-term stability based on 30-min UV-ozone treated Ti3C2T x film. This work demonstrated the potential of MXenes-only for working as ETLs and opened up their use in photovoltaics. In 2021, Wang et al. explored the application of Ti3C2T x MXene as ETL through a room-temperature solution process with oxygen plasma treatment as shown in Fig. 7(c). The surface terminations and properties of MXene can be modified by single oxygen plasma treatment, where the parts of TiC bonds are broken and generated TiO bonds are randomly distributed on the surface. Thus, tunable WFs of MXene with enhanced electrical transport and reduced defect density are obtained, rendering a better performance of PSCs and expanding the study of MXenes surface regulation in optoelectronic devices [139]. To further regulate the properties of Ti3C2T x MXene serving as ETL, we carried out the oxidation of Ti3C2T x hydrocolloid to tune its desirability in low-temperature processed PSCs [66]. Fig. 7(d) shows the predicted crystal structures of Ti3C2T x MXene with different oxidation degrees carried out by Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) code based on density functional theory (DFT). The oxidized process of Ti3C2T x MXene can arise more Ti–O bonds and effectively decrease the macroscopic defects of the ETL films, while a metal-to-semiconductor transition occurred after heavy oxidation. Distinct oxidation degrees of Ti3C2T x induce different shifts of energy levels, which improves the compatibility of the perovskite with ETLs (Fig. 7e). Thus, increased electron mobilities of ETLs including promoted electron transfer and reduced recombination at interface are achieved, arousing a champion PCE of 18.29% based on a hybrid of oxidized and pristine Ti3C2T x . Furthermore, on the basis of the advantages of oxidized Ti3C2T x MXene, a hybridization of SnO2 with an in-situ oxidized Ti3C2T x -electron transport bilayer was conducted for higher performance PSCs [67]. Better matched energy levels and enhanced electron mobility of the hybridization generate increased electron extraction and reduced recombination between the perovskite layer and ETL interface. Thus, an improved PCE from 17.68% to 20.09% is obtained, along with an 82% maintenance rate of stability after 1000 h storage in air. These two studies demonstrate great potential of MXene-derived materials for applications in photovoltaic devices. Beyond the applications of Ti3C2T x MXene, Nb2CT x with different surface terminations and its opto-electrical properties are deeply investigated by Zhang et al. [140]. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), the WFs of Nb2CT x MXene tuned by different surface terminations are analyzed according to the shifts of vacuum level (E vac) and Fermi level (E F). The groups of OH and NH2 can donate the electrons to Nb2CT x that upshift the E F and downshift the E vac, while the F downshifts both E vac and E F. The WFs of Nb2CT x MXene with different treatment of N2H4 exhibit decreased values from 4.65 to 4.34 eV. The matched energy levels and downward band-bending are beneficial for charge transport at the perovskite/T-Nb2CT x interface, while blocking the holes transfer from perovskite layer to ETL. Coupled with hydrogen bonds formed with iodine ions, the growth of the perovskite films is oriented with higher crystallization, thus achieving a champion PCE of 21.79% along with the corresponding high PCE of 19.15% and 18.31% for those flexible and large-area devices, respectively (Fig. 8b). In the meantime, the devices maintain 93% stability without encapsulation after 1500 h of storage, demonstrating broad application prospects of Nb2CT x MXene in photovoltaics. 3.3 MXenes as HTLs The HTL plays an important role in PSCs for holes transfer and crystallization of perovskite film [141]. Recently, Nb2CT x MXene nanosheets with functionalized surface terminations were prepared as HTLs in inverted-structured PSCs with the architecture of ITO/Nb2CT x /perovskite/PCBM/Ag (Fig. 9 a) by Zhang et al. [142]. The surface termination of Nb2CT x MXene is regulated via oxygen plasma process, which generates O functional terminations on the surface and alters the WFs in the meantime. In this case, owing to the promoted surface dipoles and the charge transport from Nb2CT x to the terminations, an upward band-bending is obtained at the interface of perovskite/HTL (Fig. 9c). Thus, an enhanced hole transfer with reduced charge recombination is obtained, arousing a champion PCE of 20.74% with long-term stability and barely hysteresis shown in Fig. 9(b). In addition, the flexible and large area of 0.99 cm2 devices with the champion PCE of 17.26% and 17.94% in sequence based on modulated Nb2CT x MXene are achieved. Subsequently, Du et al. reported that the Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets doped with silane coupling agent vinyltris (2-methoxyethoxylsilane) (SCA) was fabricated by spray-coating as HTLs in PSCs (Fig. 9d) [143]. Fig. 9(e) shows the schematic diagram of the device based on Ti3C2T x -SCA, where SCA can effectively modulate the distribution of Ti3C2T x nanosheets, leading to flat and pin-hole free Ti3C2T x films that are beneficial for holes extraction and transfer with the reduced interface resistance. Finally, a champion PCE of 13.65% based on spray-coated Ti3C2T x is obtained, highlighting the potential role of Ti3C2T x as HTL in low-cost, large-area PSCs and providing more possibilities for future research of photovoltaics. The key parameters for MXenes as ETLs/HTLs of PSCs are summarized in Table S3. In general, ETLs and HTLs in PSCs are mainly spotlighted on semiconductors, as the metallic materials like MXenes usually form Schottky barriers with perovskite layer that block the carriers transfer and reduce the device performance. Thus, the regulation of MXenes’ surface functional terminations that are closely related to their WFs is extremely crucial. In-depth theoretical calculations and semiconductor-like surface terminations are required for designs of heterojunction with perovskite layer that benefit for charge transfer characteristics. Besides, the oxidation processes of MXenes are noteworthy, where the transitions from metallic to semiconductor effectively expand their applications. Moreover, the control of concentration and the preparation process is necessary for fabricating high-conductive and large-area MXenes films without pin-holes and defects, so as to reduce the non-radiative recombination at the interfaces. 3.4 Interface engineering of MXenes Interface engineering is extremely crucial to promote the extraction ability in PSCs, where high conductive MXenes are effective for suppressing surface traps and blocking recombination by virtue of their unique properties. In 2020, Wang et al. employed Ti3C2T x MXene between SnO2 ETL and FTO as an interlayer to boost the electron mobility and charge transfer [144]. The MXene-regulated SnO2 ETL provides a preferable morphology for better crystallization of perovskite film with less defect density, while the suitable alignment of energy levels is favorable for charge transport and suppressing non-radiative recombination (Fig. 10 a). Based on the significant enhancements, a stabilized champion PCE of 20.65% with negligible hysteresis was eventually achieved. In addition, MXene/metallic single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) composites were prepared and served as an interlayer between SnO2 ETL and perovskite layer for PSCs by Bati et al. [145]. The architecture of the device with the interfacial SnO2/CNT layer between the ITO and perovskite as well as its cross-sectional SEM image is shown in Fig. 10(b). With the optimized composition, an enhanced PCE over 21% is obtained, which is attributed to the improved charge extraction, carrier mobility, and reduced defect density at the interface between ETL and perovskite layer. These two studies demonstrate the effective approaches of Ti3C2T x MXene as interlayers in further optimization of performances for PSCs. To address the issues of low efficiency and high energy loss caused by non-radiative recombination of CsPbI3 perovskite films, functionalized Ti3C2F2 QDs are introduced as interlayer for the interface passivation of PSCs by Xu et al. [146]. The devices structure is shown in Fig. 10(c), where the Ti3C2F2 QDs interface passivator mainly exhibits three effects as follows: (1) the inserted Ti3C2F2 QDs can tune the band alignment of perovskite films and offer an effective approach for holes transfer; (2) the defects of perovskite film can be passivated by Ti3C2F2 QDs interlayer, rendering reduced non-radiative recombination; (3) Ti3C2F2 QDs interlayer is beneficial for blocking water invasion that results in enhanced stability of PSCs. Therefore, a high PCE of 20.44% with a stability of 93% retention after 600 h is finally achieved. Additionally, the surface passivation of inorganic perovskite CsPbBr3 by Ti3C2T x MXene was reported by Chen et al. [147]. The energy levels of the device by inserting Ti3C2T x and its carrier transport mechanism at the interface are illustrated in Fig. 10(d). The appropriate band matching of MXene can provide the pathway and accelerate holes transfer from perovskite to the carbon electrode with reduced recombination. Functional surface terminations of Ti3C2T x also exhibit strong interaction with under-coordinated Pb atoms that significantly optimize the defects of perovskite films, thus leading to the enhanced performance of PSCs. Furthermore, a composite of Bathocuproine (BCP) and MXene interlayer was employed at the interface between ETL and metal cathode in inverted PSCs by Yakusheva et al. [148]. Fig. 10(e and f) illustrates the schematic diagrams of the device with MXenes-BCP interlayer and the related energy levels of PSCs. The role of BCP is crucial for the uniform distribution of Ti3C2T x in the formation of a homogeneous surface layer, while an improved PCE from 16.45% to 17.46% based on proper ratio of Ti3C2T x is obtained. The enhanced performance is mainly attributed to the better electron extraction and the high conductivity of the ETL stack. Similarly, the MXene regulations of defect passivation, carrier mobility, and band alignment for PSCs were studied by Chava et al. as well [149], demonstrating the great impact of MXenes for interface engineering of PSCs. Tunable WFs by surface terminations render MXenes outstanding conductivities and suitable matching energy levels as interfacial layers in PSCs. Their unique properties can offer paths for charge transfer, thus leading to carrier extraction and performance enhancement. However, the studies are mainly concentrated on Ti3C2T x , more diverse MXenes with different surface terminations are required to deeply enhance charge transfer characteristics of PSCs. Meanwhile, the future studies should pay more attention to the surface terminations modulation of MXenes, which is directly associated with their WFs and optoelectronic properties. Understanding of passivation on perovskite and charge transfer optimization requires in-depth demonstration by theoretical calculations. Besides, appropriate band alignments are also of significance for developing new structures of MXenes with superior interactions in PSCs. 3.5 MXenes as electrodes The highly conductive top cathode electrode plays an essential role in efficient PSCs, while the noble metal electrodes, Au, Ag etc., limit the further industrial applications due to the high costs [150]. Alternatively, the remarkable conductivity, low cost, mechanical robustness, and tunable WFs for band alignment enable MXenes to be ideal candidates for top electrodes of PSCs [151,152]. In 2019, Cao et al. employed Ti3C2T x MXene as a back electrode via a simple hot-pressing method in noble-metal-free PSCs for the first time and Fig. 11 (a) shows the schematic illustration of the Ti3C2T x electrode synthesis process [153]. In this case, the Ti3C2T x electrode can contact tightly with perovskite layer without any interfacial crack as shown in Fig. 11(b). The corresponding energy level diagram is shown in Fig. 11(c), where the WF of Ti3C2T x is determined to be −4.96 eV that matches the valance band of perovskite layer; both electrons and holes can be extracted and transported to each electrode. On basis of these, the PSCs based on Ti3C2T x electrode deliver an enhanced PCE of 13.83% with the adjustment of key parameters, which is 27% higher than that based on carbon electrode. Moreover, thanks to the seamless interfacial contact, the device exhibits better stability with a retention of 60% after the storage for 360 h. In 2020, Mi et al. employed a mixed carbon electrode consisting of 1D structure carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and 2D Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets for electrode engineering in PSCs [154]. Fig. 11(d) illustrated the device architecture and the corresponding cross-section SEM images in a low and a large magnification. The full-covered perovskite layer can be seen in SEM images that indicates good generation and separation of electron and hole pairs under light illumination. Differing from the pure carbon electrode showing a point-to-point contact, the mixed electrode exhibits the tight interface contact and offers a network structure and multi-dimensional pathway for charge transport. A remarkable PCE of 7.09% is eventually obtained on basis of the mixed electrode, providing an effective method to prepare high-performance HTL-free devices and demonstrating the potential for large-area applications of PSCs in the future. Furthermore, a composite transparent electrode based on AgNW:MXene with excellent mechanical performance was conducted for flexible PSCs by Chen et al. [155]. Fig. 11(e) shows the fabrication process of AgNW:MXene flexible transparent electrodes and the corresponding schematic illustration of flexible PSCs is exhibited in Fig. 11(f). The obtained AgNW:MXene electrode demonstrates a superior photoelectric property with a low sheet resistance of 10.91 Ω sq−1 and high transmittance of 82.84%. On basis of these, an excellent PCE of 20.22% for the flexible device is achieved, which is attributed to the better crystallization and enhanced light absorption of perovskite film induced by AgNW:MXene electrode (Fig. 11g). Besides, the devices based on AgNW:MXene electrode exhibit high mechanical robustness that maintains 90% of the pristine PCE after 1000 bending cycles at a curvature radius of 4 mm, indicating a great potential for the developments of high-performance flexible PSCs. The key parameters for MXenes as interlayers and electrodes of PSCs are summarized in Table S4. Taking the advantages of low-cost, high transparency, simple fabrication, and solution preparable, MXenes are proposed to be a promising alternative to expensive electrodes. The suitable band alignment and superior conductivity can not only enhance the charge transfer dynamics, but also promote the surface-active areas and facilitate carrier extraction inside the perovskite. On basis of this, understanding of MXenes/perovskite interface modulation and large-area fabrication processes like spray-coating needs further investigation. Besides, how to block the oxidation process of MXenes and maintain long-term stability is also need to be concerned. Thus, modifying MXenes with hydrophobic surface terminations and developing hybrid electrodes with metallic or carbon-based materials seem to be effective methods. We have a strong sense of confidence to render MXenes competitive for large-area and flexible optoelectronic devices. Apart from the performance optimization of PSCs, the stability is a key parameter and challenge for industrial exploitation as well. MXenes have been demonstrated to work as a variety of roles in PSCs, of which different functions exhibit distinct impacts on stability optimization. When MXenes serve as additive in perovskite film, the nucleus of perovskite generated around the MXene nanosheets and the number of the nucleus are suppressed, indicating larger perovskite crystals with better performance [60]. Besides, the surface termination like –Cl of MXenes can form strong interaction with Pb2+, leading to regular-grew and better crystallized perovskite films with less trap states [114]. Thus, the better crystallized perovskite film with less defect states can offer an enhanced stability for devices usage. Moreover, when MXenes work as interlayers or back electrodes, the hydrophobic surface of MXene can effectively restrict the penetration of moisture from air into perovskite films, or even have a passivation on them, thus leading to long-term stability of PSCs [148,153]. The superior usage of MXenes for stability of PSCs further demonstrated their great potential in photovoltaics. As MXenes play diverse roles in PSCs, the standards for materials selecting and designing for performance improvement are not unique. Generally, the applied MXenes mainly have superior conductivities, charge carrier mobilities, appropriate energy level matching, high optical transmittance, low cost, good mechanical properties, long-term stabilities, etc. Meanwhile, according to the different functions summarized in Table S5, we can further confirm the choice or design for required MXenes in PSCs. Since the relevant works are still in the initial stage and mainly concentrate on the most studied Ti3C2T x MXene, more diverse MXenes with unique photovoltaic properties are necessary to be simulated and explored to open up the opportunities to achieve high-performance PSCs. We have great confidence for the bright future of MXene-based PSCs. 4 Summary and prospect Since the first exploration of Ti3C2T x MXene in PSCs from 2018, this emerging system has gained immense attention and opened up a wide spectrum of researches. At present, not only limited to Ti3C2T x , increasing applications of other MXenes in photovoltaic systems have been reported. This review systematically summarized and explained different approaches to fabricate MXenes, along with their detailed properties of physics and chemistry. Among them, wet chemical processing that uses fluoride compounds as etchants to remove A layers from MAX phase has been a widely-applied method to obtain MXenes, thus leading to abundant and various surface chemical morphology. On basis of this, MXenes nanosheets can be regulated diversely and applied as different roles in PSCs, while the corresponding methods were systematically discussed and analyzed. For instance, MXenes can be used as additives, ETLs/HTLs, interfacial layers, and electrodes through different structures and surface design. The use of MXenes as additives can enhance the crystallinity and provide morphology control of solution-processed perovskites, as well as supply a “bridge” for charge transfer and optimize the interfaces due to their metallic conductivity, high carrier mobility, and unique 2D structure, giving rise to enhanced performance of PSCs. In addition, tunable surface functional groups allow MXenes to get a wide range of WF, enabling them to work as ETLs and HTLs, respectively. The tunability of WF to optimize the band alignments also has a great potential for tuning the WF of perovskites, leading to better matching of energy levels in PSCs. Owing to the unique properties, MXenes have already been a promising alternative for further development of efficient, stable, and low-cost photovoltaic devices. Despite the remarkable achievements of MXene-based PSCs, there still remains various challenges that need to be handled to ensure long-term practical applications of devices in the future. Overall, as the first application of MXenes in PSCs began in 2018, the relevant works were still in the initial stage and mainly based on the experiments to explore the feasibility. Hence, the simulation and theoretical studies are necessary to make sure the accuracy of the changes in the properties of regulated MXenes by different surface functional groups and their interaction with each functional layer in PSCs, which can guide the experiments in the meantime. While understanding the mechanism of MXenes, the dosage also needs to be further investigated and optimized. Such as the doping in perovskite films, a low concentration may have no obvious effect on the crystallization and carrier mobility, while a high concentration may adversely affect the quality of perovskite films. Hence, the appropriate concentration is necessary for achieving better performance of devices. Comparing to perovskite materials, MXenes have confirmed relatively better stability. However, oxidation reaction will also occur when MXenes are exposed to the ambient environment for a long time due to the defective sites on the surface, which would affect their own resistance and degrade the device performance. Thus, suitable passivation or encapsulation is necessary for altering the oxidation kinetics. Besides, the key properties of MXenes including conductivity, surface terminations, WF, stability etc. are closely related to the fabrication process. To obtain high quality, large scale, and low cost MXene nanosheets with accurately controllable properties, it is essential to develope novel and appropriate fabrication methods. In addition, during the conventional etching process by HF, the strong corrosive and hazardous properties need to be carefully considered. To realize high safety and environmental friendliness, exploring new synthesis of MXenes with high purity and quality has also gained significant attention. Nowadays, more than 100 MXenes have been theoretically predicted as well as more than 30 different stoichiometric combinations of MXenes have been experimentally fabricated and adjusted by replacing or changing the ratio of M and X elements. Nevertheless, almost all the studies in PSCs were based on the first discovered MXene, Ti3C2T x , while only several other MXenes like Nb2CT x , V2CT x , and Mo2CT x have been applied recently. There still remains large number of unexplored MXenes, which will open up the diverse possibilities of unique and outstanding properties for performance improvement in PSCs. Consequently, MXene-based PSCs still have plenty of room for optimization and will achieve a great progress in the near future. Overall, given that MXenes have demonstrated remarkable achievements and to accomplish the deeper application of PSCs performance, some suggestions and prospects are presented blow: (1) besides the already applied Ti3C2T x , Nb2CT x , V2CT x and Mo2CT x , more diverse MXenes with unique photovoltaic properties are necessary to be explored to open up the opportunities to achieve PSCs with high performance; (2) taking further insight of the modulation of surface functional groups on the Fermi Level and optoelectronic properties of MXenes based on theoretical guidance and experimental examination; (3) deep understanding of the effect of tunable MXenes interacted with perovskite or other functional layers on the energy level structure; (4) exploring the appropriate passivation methods or further developing new structure and system based on oxidized MXenes while figuring out the mechanism of the performance degradation for exposing in air; (5) modulating appropriate concentration and preparation process of MXenes for fabricating high-conductive and large-area films without pin-holes and defects; (6) regulating MXenes to prevent the oxidation process, thus maintaining their high performance and stability; (7) the advantages of tunable electrical properties, flexibility, high transparency, and low cost make MXenes suitable for developing large-scale flexible PSCs or even self-powered integrated components, which enrich and provide more possibilities to realize photovoltaic devices with high performance. Lin Yang received his PhD degree in condensed physics from Jilin University in 2022. He is now a postdoctoral fellow at Northeast Normal University, Key Laboratory for UV-Emitting Materials and Technology of Ministry of Education. His current research interests focus on MXenes, perovskite solar cells and photodetectors. Peng Li received his PhD degree from the Northeast Normal University, Changchun, China, in 2017. Currently, he is an associate professor at the Key Laboratory for UV-Emitting Materials and Technology of Ministry of Education in Northeast Normal University. His current research interests include wide bandgap semiconductor materials and devices. Jiangang Ma received his PhD degree from the Changchun Institute of Optics, Fine Mechanics and Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun, China, in 2004. Currently, he is a professor at the Key Laboratory for UV-Emitting Materials and Technology of Ministry of Education in Northeast Normal University. His current research interests include wide bandgap semiconductor materials and optoelectronic devices Xintong Zhang obtained his PhD in physical chemistry from Jilin University in 1998. He worked at Jilin University (1998-2001), the University of Tokyo (2001-2003), and Kanagawa Academy of Science and Technology (2003-2007), and then joined in School of Physics, Northeast Normal University (2007-till present), where he is a professor of materials physics and chemistry. His main research interests focus on materials and devices for light energy utilization, such as quantum dot solar cells, perovskite solar cells, photocatalysis, photothermocatalysis, and plasma-enhanced photocatalysis. Xiao-Feng Wang obtained his PhD in physical chemistry from Kwansei Gakuin University in 2006. He worked at Kwansei Gakuin University (2006– 2008), Energy Research Department of the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (2008–2009), Gifu University (2009), Yamagata University (2010–2013), Toin Yokohama University (2014), and then moved to Jilin University (2015– till present) where he is a professor in college of physics, Department of Condensed Physics. His main research interests focus on new energy physics and materials, especially on solar cells and photocatalytic water splitting. Yichun Liu received his PhD degree in condensed physics from the Changchun Institute of Optics, Fine Mechanics and Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun, China, in 1995. He received the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars in 2007. During 2012–2023, he worked as President of Northeast Normal University and elected academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2021. His research interests include semiconductor materials and optoelectronic devices.

coredata.dc:description: Perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have been developed over the past decade as the forefront of the state-of-the-art photovoltaic technologies owing to their high efficiency and low cost, where nanostructured functional materials play key roles in performance optimization. As a versatile class of two-dimensional (2D) materials, transition metal carbides/nitrides MXenes have gained enormous attentions in PSCs since 2018 due to their superior properties such as excellent metallic conductivity, abundant surface functional groups, tunable work functions, high optical transparency, and mechanical robustness. The explorations of MXenes are of significance in performance promotion and commercialization expansion of devices. As such, this review focuses on the diversified advantages of MXenes, comprehensively summarizing their applications and developments in PSCs as additives, electron/hole transporting layers, interfacial engineering layers, and electrodes in sequence and explaining the relevant mechanisms behind. Simultaneously, the problems emerged from the related studies are considered and the corresponding suggestions like opening up the type of MXenes usage, taking further insight of the modulation of surface termination groups on Fermi levels, understanding the effect on energy level structures of perovskite or other functional layers, and realizing commercialization, etc. are provided for the future in-depth explorations. This review is intended to provide overall perspective of the current status of MXenes and highlight the direction for the future advancements in MXenes design and processes towards efficient, stable, large-area, and low-cost PSCs.
